<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by the speaking voice. And the 
            <choice>
              <sic>l tes</sic>
              <corr>lutes</corr>
            </choice> and the 
            <choice>
              <sic>cithersn</sic>
              <corr>citherns</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>have</sic>
              <corr>gave</corr>
            </choice> lilt and 
            <choice>
              <sic>rhym</sic>
              <corr>rhythm</corr>
            </choice> and melody to the spoken word.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">His mind was full of half sung half 
            <choice>
              <sic>spoekn</sic>
              <corr>spoken</corr>
            </choice> words;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">full of undifferentiated words; 
            <choice>
              <sic>ol</sic>
              <corr>old</corr>
            </choice> words, new words; French words</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Latin words. No grammar bound them tightly together.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">They were elastic. They could stretch to any 
            <choice>
              <sic>lgneth</sic>
              <corr>length</corr>
            </choice>. They 
            <choice>
              <sic>cd</sic>
              <corr>could</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">could 
            <choice>
              <sic>refelct</sic>
              <corr>reflect</corr>
            </choice> many colours; they could 
            <choice>
              <sic>fol ow</sic>
              <corr>follow</corr>
            </choice> many tunes,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">they could be danced to, and sung to. But they could not</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">follow the words of the speaking voice. For a moment then</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">there is a pause on the threshold of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>gre t</sic>
              <corr>great</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>lizabethan</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">room. The artist is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxm. <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sahekeapere</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs> may be <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mich" key="Michelangelo">
              <choice>
                <sic>Michael</sic>
                <corr>Michelangelo</corr>
              </choice></rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mich">Angelo</rs>; 
            <choice>
              <sic>Soenser</sic>
              <corr>Spenser</corr>
            </choice> may be <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-perg" key="Pergolesi">Pergolesi</rs>. It seems possible that the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great English art may not be the art of poetry.</l>
